item.title: Static content twice the speed with lighttpd
item.description: I have done a basic benchmark between Apache 2.2 and lighttpd 1.4 for serving the static files on this WordPress installation, using the Apache “ab” benchmarking tool. Apache is running prefork MPM, mod_ssl and mod_php5. LightTPD is running with minimal modules loaded for serving static content. Both are running on the same machine, on a Linux 2.6.17 kernel. Here is the diff of the outputs from each ab benchmark, requesting a static CSS file 10,000 times without HTTP keepalive:

item.title: Browser Cookie Limits
item.description: I’ve been working on a website where some users have reported their “Remember Me” session is often being lost by Internet Explorer. The cause appears to be Internet Explorer rejecting cookies beyond a total of 20 for the domain. Interestingly, Internet Explorer seems to be the only browser to correctly enforce the 20 cookies per domain limit specified by RFC 2965 Here are the limits enforced by the handful of browsers I have tested:

item.title: Project Idea: XML-RPC desktop client/debugger
item.description: While working with XML-RPC in PHP, I've been frustrated that the only desktop debugging client I could find was the XML-RPC Client for Mac, which doesn't do me much good in Windows. I'm going to try and find time to have a go at building such a tool for Windows, either as a Java application or a XUL Firefox Extension - neither of which I have ever written a useful application with.

item.title: for no compelling reason...
item.description: From Netscape’s Preliminary Specification for HTTP cookies: The state object is called a cookie, for no compelling reason.
